Magical Girl Miracle☆Monomi is a minigame in which players control Monomi fighting off against waves of cute monsters. Island Mode, which is available after clearing the game once, is an alternate mode where the students don't go through the killing game and instead aim to make friends with everyone and earn Hope Shards. This allows players to bond with characters more easily than in the main story mode. Danganronpa IF, a short story depicting an alternate storyline for Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, is also unlocked after clearing the game once.

Source: Wikipedia, "Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

156313.name: Mummy's Mask Player's Guide
156313.description:
From the publisher's website:

The Mummy's Mask Player's Guide gives players all the spoiler-free information, inspiration, and new rules they'll need to create characters prepared for delving into the adventure and intrigue of the Mummy's Mask Adventure Path.

Within, players of this campaign will find everything they need to create character backgrounds tied to personalities and events vital to Pathfinder Adventure Path's exploration of some of the many ancient tombs and vast deserts of Osirion, along with new campaign—specific traits to give bold adventurers the edge they'll need to take on the strange and deadly threats faced on their quest. This player’s guide also features a view of the city of Wati where the adventure begins, as well as various class options and advice for heroes ready to explore the nation of Osirion’s many ruins.

Adventurers don't need to delve forgotten tombs unprepared! Gather your allies and let the Mummy's Mask Player's Guide start your trip into the thrill and danger of the blistering desert.

156315.name: Panchadevi
156315.description:
In times of greed pervades the lives of the Goddesses, the war of no longer inevitable. Five Goddess consisting of earth, water, fire, air, and ether agreed to compete for "sixth element". Elements which can not only increase strength but also can make the Goddess of Life.

In Sanskrit, Panchadevi means five goddesses, this is a card game that uses dice were also in play. So the factor of luck and strategy, interplay to be a winner.

Each player will play one of the five goddesses and fight each other to gain victory points (VP) by collecting card of elements. Each card has a different VP and each player was released to collect cards of any type of element. However, if the player manages to collect cards of the same elements as his goddess then amount of VP of that card mentioned multiplied by two.

The game will be more challenging because if the player collects more than three cards of the same elements, then VP of a number of card mentioned has aborted and each card will only be worth 1VP. At the end of the game, the whole of VP will be totaled and the player with the highest VP is declared the winner.

156316.description:
Peppermint is a pony which every child would like. A pony to love! But a pony needs to be taken care or regularly. It needs to be groomed, fed and its saddlery and cleaning utensils needs to be looked after.

The aim of the game is to collect the most peppermint medals.

In order to get those the player needs a set of 5 different tiles. The tiles are acquired by rolling the colour on a 6-sided dice with the horseshoe acting as a joker. A player can keep any colour that is rolled on his turn but whenever a colour comes up a second time he loses all tiles collected so far in this turn.
In addition players can trade coloured tiles among themselves in order to complete sets.

So children will learn about risk management.
156316.name: Rund um Pony Peppermint

156318.description:
After many years of peace, the heroes of Andor have received a cry for help from Far Hadria, and they immediately undertake a perilous voyage to the North. On board an old sailing ship, they travel to foreign islands and struggle to protect the coasts from terrible sea monsters. What's more, time and time again they find themselves challenged by raging storms and the unleashed power of the sea itself.

Legends of Andor: Journey to the North, the first large expansion for Legends of Andor, includes a new map of the northern region of Andor, new legends, and more.
156318.name: Legends of Andor: Journey to the North
boardgameaccessory: Legends of Andor: Journey to the North – Soundtrack – "Into the North"
boardgamepodcastepisode: DATENIGHT Episode 1 - Legends of Andor

156319.description: A 33-card expansion, that includes new companies, pro players, and E-Sport events and competitions.
156319.name: Game Developerz: E-Sports

156320.description: A 33-card expansion that includes: indie companies, indie gurus, and indie stories.
156320.name: Game Developerz: Indie Games

156321.description: A 33-card expansion, which includes: new mobile companies, pick-up-and-play games, and mobile fun facts.
156321.name: Game Developerz: Mobile

156325.name: Aventurischer Bote (Issue 156 - Nov/Dez 2012)
156325.description:
Issue 155 of the periodical Aventurischer Bote, the in- and outgame magazine for "Das Schwarze Auge".

The outer part contains outgame information and is separately numbered from the inner part, which contains ingame articles.

156326.name: Aventurischer Bote (Issue 157 - Jan/Feb 2013)
156326.description:
Issue 157 of the periodical Aventurischer Bote, the in- and outgame magazine for "Das Schwarze Auge".

The outer part contains outgame information and is separately numbered from the inner part, which contains ingame articles.

156327.name: Aventurischer Bote (Issue 158 - Mar/Apr 2013)
156327.description:
Issue 158 of the periodical Aventurischer Bote, the in- and outgame magazine for "Das Schwarze Auge".

The outer part contains outgame information and is separately numbered from the inner part, which contains ingame articles.

156328.description:
Potty Ponies is a roll and move dice throwing game where players will land on illustrated squares depicting country life. Most of the squares incorporate childlike humour coming directly from the designer's rural experiences.

Players are represented by ponies. They collect apples, carrots and sugar lumps as they progress around the board and encounter other animals. At the end of the game children have to use a score pad to add up their points.
156328.name: Potty Ponies And Friends!

156329.name: Stone Orcs (Pathfinder)
156329.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventurers encounter all kinds of strange and wonderful things.

In this new supplement, adventurers encounter the society and culture of the stone orcs along with racial stats and some new equipment options.

156330.name: Holy Fount (Legend)
156330.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventurers encounter all kinds of strange and wonderful things.

In this supplement adventurers will discover the mystery and serenity of the holy fount. Receive 11 different blessings and 11 different holy items to help you in your war against evil. Along with 7 new divine spells and 5 new heroic abilities.

Take up the cause of goodness with new backgrounds such as the Parishioner and Puritan and 3 new professions including the Confessor, Mediator and Missionary.

Or maybe you'll have an encounter with the white stag, the very manifestation of the godly power of the fount that protects it against evil.

Also included is a new cult: The Order of the White Stag who direct and guide new supplicants that want to be blessed in this holy place.

Come and enjoy the serenity of the holy fount today!

156331.name: Skeletons (Legend)
156331.description:
From publisher blurb:

Enter the world of undead skeletons with rules that allow you to make regular skeletons more unique to even play them as player characters!

Choose from new backgrounds such as the Dead Lands Survivor or a Death Cult Upbringing.

Start with a unique profession like the cultist, dead hunter, death priest, death scout or the harbinger.

Choose from 29 unique heroic abilties that are for skeletons only!

Battle or play from four new skeletons such as the Skeleton Barbarian, Elemental Skeleton, the Unholy Skeleton or the Skeleton Mage.

Select from 18 new necromancy spells with some slight new rules on how to cast such evil magic.

Lastly, upgrade weapons with 5 new weapon properties that can cause any enemy to cower in fear!

Dare to enter the world of skeletons in this new supplement by Solace Games!

156332.name: VonAnstee's Library
156332.description:
From publisher blurb:

Enter the library of the vampire Henry VonAnstee and find lore that will help you advance skills and learn spells. Of course being admitted to such a library has its requirements and the vampire librarian won't let just anyone in.

There also seems to be some underlying hidden motive of VonAnstee's. What is he really up to?

Inside you will find:

4 new occupations
4 new feats
4 new undead creatures.




Do you dare to try and enter the library?

156333.name: Venator Praeda
156333.description:
Are you a hunter or prey?
In this game, the roles can be reversed, and that you are a hunter or a boar makes no difference: You have to survive!

Abstract strategy game where players move disc-shaped pieces across a functional and original board.

The Huntsmen can move forward diagonally and vertically for one or two space. the first move of every huntsmen pieces is only in forward vertically for one or two spaces.
The Wild Boars can move forward diagonally and vertically for one, two, or three space. the first move of every Boars pieces is only in forward vertically for one, two, or three spaces.
The huntsmen can attack the Wild Boars every time, with legit moves.
The Wild Boars can attack only if they made the TURNABOUT, and opponent pieces didn't, or if they didn't make the TURNABOUT, but the opponent pieces did, with legit moves.

When a piece reach a square occupied by an opponent piece, with legit moves and the right conditions, the attack is valid; if there is no right condition (Like TURNABOUT Boar and TURNABOUT Hunt) is not valid.

The piece attacked is removed from the board.

For Obtain the TURNABOUT a piece have to reach a start square of the opponent piece. Now, their moves are backwards.
For cancel the TURNABOUT, simply reach a start squre of your team.

wins the game who removes or blocks all opposing pieces.

156334.name: The Skeleton
156334.description:
From publisher blurb:

Get up lazy bones, you've got work to do!

Whether you are a necromantic experiment gone wrong, a soul that escaped Death's grasp, or something else entirely, the skeleton is a chance to play something out of the ordinary...or maybe to give an unfortunate character a second chance.

The skeleton is a made of bones but is as hard as nails, using a Bones mechanic to reduce damage, as well as create weapons, help out its allies, and more. There are a few extra pages with that give you some added insights that we learned during our playtest, what various mechanics mean, as well as some extra moves that did not quite make the cut.

Will things work out better this time? Will you avenge any wrongs? Will you spare someone from a similar fate?

Roll the bones, and play to find out what happens.

156335.name: Vancomancer
156335.description:
From publisher blurb:

In ages gone a thousand spells were known to sorcery, and the wizards effected their wills. Today, as Earth dies, a hundred spell remain to man’s knowledge, and these have come to us through the ancient books.

-The Dying Earth, Chapter 1

The Vancomancer is a variant of the wizard that is more in line with what you would expect from Jack Vance's The Dying Earth; there is no daily limitation on magic, you can cast spells right out of your book (if you have enough time), and the spells do not have levels.

Those are not the only ways in which it differs from the standard wizard, though: aside from kind of one, the new advanced moves let you do stuff like grow minions in flesh vats, improve upon your manse, impress people with your magic, summon and bind sandestins, create magic items, and so on.

Finally, there are 25 spells--18 simple and 7 complex--to get you started, including The Excellent Prismatic Spray, The Omnipotent Sphere, and Felojun's 2nd Hypnotic Spell.

boardgamehonor: 2014 Golden Geek Best Solo Board Game Nominee
156336.description:
You are a Dreamwalker, lost in a mysterious labyrinth, and you must discover the oneiric doors before your dreamtime runs out – or you will remain trapped forever!

You may wander through the chambers of dreams, hoping that chance will reveal the doors, or you can linger in each type of room. In both cases, you will have to deal with the slithering Nightmares, which haunt the hallways of the labyrinth.

Onirim is a solo/cooperative card game. You (and a partner, if you wish) must work (together) against the game to gather the eight Door cards before the deck runs out; you can obtain those Door cards either by playing cards of the same color three turns in a row, or by discarding (under specific circumstances) one of your powerful Key cards. In both cases you will have to decide the best use of each card in your hand and carefully play around the Nightmares. Those cards are hidden in the deck and will trigger painful dilemmas when drawn...

Seven mini-expansions, all standalone and compatible with one another, are included with the second edition of Onirim, including these three that were in the first edition of the game:


"The Towers" introduces a new type of card that allows more searching and deck manipulation, while also imposing an additional victory condition.



"Happy Dreams and Dark Premonitions" adds evil time bombs that will impede your progress at predictable moments of your quest as well as helpful but unreliable allies.



In "The Book of Steps Lost and Found", you must find the eight Door cards in a randomly given order and may remove discarded cards from the game to cast powerful spells that will help you complete this difficult task.


Apart from these three from the first edition, there are four new modules in the Onirim 2nd edition box. Just like previously, each module consists of something that makes the game easier and something that makes the game harder:


"The Glyphs" introduces a fourth symbol on location cards (apart from Key, Sun and Moon), which makes it easier to compose the row of unrepeated symbols. Player must then find one extra door of each color (so 12 doors in total) to win



"The Dreamcatchers" are four cards that "guard" the Limbo piles. The Limbo pile stays with Dreamcatcher until some effect allows the player to shuffle the pile back to the deck... if all Dreamcatchers are full and new cards should come to Limbo, a Dreamcatcher is discarded and his cards shuffled back. Also, four new "Lost Dreams" cards are supposed to be in Limbo at the end of the game, as an extra winning condition - so discarding all Dreamcatchers means loss.



"The Crossroads and Dead Ends" introduce location cards with a given symbol (3 Sun, 2 Moon, 1 Key), but serving as any color "joker". It also contains 10 "Dead End" cards, that remain in players hand (un-discard-able on its own) and block her 5-cards hand limit... until a player discards the whole hand (=the only way to discard a Dead End).



"The Door To The Oniverse" brings several one-time abilities cards as "inhabitants of the Oniverse"... and one extra colorless door to find.


Apart from all those, there are a few special rules to use the dark meeple in the game (which interferes with Nightmare cards resolving), making the game easier or harder, depending on the chosen variant.
156336.name: Onirim (second edition)
boardgamepodcastepisode: #18: The Golden Ages review, Onirim on tap, Onitama & Best Treehouse Ever
1P 066 - Onirim (2nd edition)
Episode 98- Yokohama
Low Player Count - Ep 14 - Free Form
Low Player Count - Ep 20 - Our Top 5 Solo Games
Low Player Count - Ep. 10 - The Digital Mail Bag
Low Player Count - Ep. 15 - The Filler Episode
Low Player Count - Ep. 19 - The Shadi Torbey Interview
Low Player Count - Ep. 3 - High Score vs. Objective - FIGHT!
Low Player Count - Ep. 4 - Getting Ready for 'Sommer' Vacation
Low Player Count - Ep. 5 - geringe Anzahl Spieler and the Spiel des Jahres
Low Player Count - What's Your Gaming Nightmare? Giveaway!
Richard Goes Rogue: Our Roguecast Premiere
The Dice Men Cometh – Episode 153

156337.name: Super Dungeon Explore: Kaelly the Nether Strider
156337.description:
Description from Publisher:

Smoke, shadow, and dark energy twist and lurk from the scarred lands known as the Nether Rifts. From the depths of this stygian abyss the Nether Elves appear. Renowned amongst her dark kin, Kaelly is an assassin without peer. Embrace the darkness with this unique mini-boss and should any oppose you—strike from the shadows!

THIS BOX CONTAINS:

- 1 fully assembled Kaelly the Nether Strider miniature.
- Kaelly the Nether Strider mini-boss game card.
- Unique "Assassin's Crossbow" treasure card.

156338.name: Moebius Adventures Core Rules Sample Adventure: The Brigade
156338.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Moebius Adventures Core Rules Sample Adventure (The Brigade) is a taste of the Moebius Adventures system. This adventure pits a small group of adventurers against a group of mercenaries mistreating local villagers and running a protection scam. Who knows what other beasties you'll find lurking?

156339.name: Brick by Brick: Doors
156339.description:
From publisher blurb:

Every dungeon has doors. Each door has a story. More than that, every door offers a transition from one thing to the next. Some transitions are easy (no door at all or it's unlocked). Some transitions are hard (locked or trapped). Some turn out to be dead ends (blocked or jammed).

Brick by Brick: Doors offers a 14 page PDF to help guide you through creating more intricate doors as well as a one page worksheet you can use again and again to use as much or as little of the process as you desire.

Do you ever find yourself designing a dungeon or scenario and wondering what to do with the doors? Aren't they important? Most buildings have them. Yet as a game master, except for a few special occasions, I can hardly remember spending more than a second or two on any door. If it opens, shuts, and locks, that was typically good enough for me.

But what about those cases where you want something unique but don't have any inspiration?

That's where Brick by Brick: Doors comes in. Whether you walk through every single step in the book or just pick one, you roll a few dice and can see where they lead you.

From beginning to end, we work through various stages or questions of design. Pick and choose which pages to use depending on what you're after. You might go through all of them while designing a particular door for a dungeon if it's a particularly important one, or you might just pick one or two to add a bit of color or uniqueness where you'd like it to appear.

Just remember... Your door has a story to tell!

156340.name: Ghostly Effects
156340.description:
From publisher blurb:

As GMs, we create entire worlds, adventures, and characters in broad strokes, leaving the little details to sort themselves out when the time is right. But sometimes the little things need a little nudge.

Little Spaces offers a splash of inspiration for a particular space for just such an emergency.

This supplement offers a collection of 100 creepy effects to throw at your players when you need them. Quietly describing a creaking door at the bottom of the basement stairs, the odd breeze where no wind should be, or that strange shiver when a character stands in a particular spot can leave a lasting impression to haunt players for years to come...

156341.name: Abandoned Places
156341.description:
From publisher blurb:

Little Spaces: Abandoned Places offers a collection of four tables to offer inspiration to describe a the next lost place your PCs stumble into. You can get hints to help you figure out what or who is there for them to find… It starts by determining which sense you use for the description, then deciding what element you’re describing and gaining some sensory detail about that element.

For example, if you’re describing a strange hidden area whose only clues are marked by miniature markers in a mossy field (Touch/Marker/Miniature) you might get...

“The stories told of how to get to this place all involve a hidden path through a mossy field.
You must get on your hands and knees to find a series of crystalline markers showing the way.”

If that's not enough, you can determine whether the place they're coming to is occupied or not. Perhaps a group of pygmies is waiting to ambush the party as soon as they find the entrance or a family of wild animals has made its home in the brush.

Thousands of possible combinations will inspire an insane number of adventurous encounters and hidden secrets. Your players may wonder if you're secretly an explorer with knowledge of all the places lost to time and experience...

156342.name: Eine Fahrt aufs Land
156342.description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 130
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll & Move' game. Ending on a marked space follow instructions.

156343.name: Fancy Meals
156343.description:
From publisher blurb:

Little Spaces: Fancy Meals offers a collection of four tables to offer inspiration to describe a fancy meal. You can get hints to help you decide who’s cooking, what’s cooking, how it tastes, the list of ingredients, and more… It starts by determining which sense you use for the description, then deciding what element you’re describing and gaining some sensory detail about that element.

For example, if you’re describing a meal, let’s start with Smell. If we get Bowl as the element and Bitter as the descriptor…

“A bowl of some brown, viscous liquid appears before you with a splash and a spoon. The first thing you notice is the smell. Something bitter may have died in the stew pot tonight.”

Or perhaps you rolled Taste (sense), Appetizer (element), Mystery Meat (food), and Candied (descriptor)…

“Though you have no clue what kind of meat is on your plate, it looks well-prepared and sweetened with a bit of candied fruit. As you taste a forkful of the stuff, you wonder if you might not have wasted your evening as you thought when you walked in the door.”

Thousands of possible combinations will inspire an insane number of food-related encounters and culinary delights (or disasters). Your players may in fact wonder if you’re a master chef or just the ogre in the kitchen butchering the night’s meal.

156344.name: Shipwrecks
156344.description:
From publisher blurb:

Little Spaces: Shipwrecks offers a way to help generate cool descriptions of shipwrecks for your next campaign encounter… Do you need a fresh wreck washed up on the shore? Or an ancient hulk of a ship now part of the landscape and slowly washing away with each tide?

Shipwrecks provides three tables to roll on to generate the seeds of your PC’s frightful destruction. Those three tables - Sense, Descriptive Element, and Sense Descriptor - mean you never end up with a boring ship description again. You just roll a few dice and see what your brain throws out at you.

Imagine your party comes upon the remains of a big sailing vessel washed up on shore. You can use the descriptive elements to see what’s there that’s interesting and come up with some text that describes it to offer some sensory feedback.

For example, if you end up with “Sight [Sense]: Forecastle [Descriptive Element]- Ringing [Sense Descriptor]” you might come up with:

“What’s left of the ship’s forecastle has washed up on shore here. Though there’s not much to indicate what happened to the boat and crew, there’s a tiny bell ringing intermittently ringing in the wind that survived whatever foul event destroyed her.”

156345.name: Gruesome Graves
156345.description:
From publisher blurb:

Little Spaces: Gruesome Graves offers a collection of four tables to offer inspiration to describe events in the next graveyard your PCs come across. You can get hints to help you figure out what or who is there for them to find… It starts by determining which sense you use for the description, then deciding what element you’re describing and gaining some sensory detail about that element.

For example, if you’re describing an ongoing ceremony in an ancient graveyard hidden deep in the forest (Hearing/Ceremony/Marble) you might get...

“Even as you approach the small burial ground in the forest clearing, you can hear voices chanting. A white marble table gleams in the moonlight, stained with fresh wet blood. And a circle of robed individuals are passing a chalice from person to person...”

If that's not enough, you can determine whether the place they're coming to is occupied or not. Perhaps the cultists are not only performing a ceremony but raising the dead and desecrating the ancient graves...

Thousands of possible combinations will inspire an insane number of adventurous encounters and hidden secrets. Your players may wonder if you're secretly an explorer with knowledge of all the places lost to time and experience...

156346.name: Scary Basements
156346.description:
From publisher blurb:

As GMs, we create entire worlds, adventures, and characters in broad strokes, leaving the little details to sort themselves out when the time is right. But sometimes the little things need a little nudge... Little Spaces offers a splash of inspiration for a particular space for just such an emergency.

This supplement offers a collection of three random tables to offer inspiration to describe a creepy basement. What sense do you use? What sort of element are you describing? And how does the element appear?

For instance, imagine if you roll to use Touch as the sense, Tools as the element, and Sweaty as the descriptor...

"The rusted toolbox is full of an odd assortment of hammers and screwdrivers, but as you're feeling around in the box you notice that several of the tools are sweaty when you touch them... and it's not your sweat!"

More than 10,000 different combinations of factors can combine to inspire a creative masterpiece so creepy and evocative your players may wonder if YOU are the serial killer, monster, or psychopath hiding in the basement!

156347.name: Hand's Goods
156347.description:
From publisher blurb:

No matter what system you use for your games, being a game master is a perilous pastime. As soon as the players arrive with their PCs at the ready, your well-formulated plans can go off-the-rails at a moment's notice. If you have somewhere to put the PCs for a bit while you ponder your options, it can smooth things out considerably.

If you're in need of such a location on short notice, One Spot is for you! Each product in the line focuses on a different location you can easily drop into any fantasy town or city. Instantly you have a place with NPCs, descriptive text, plot hooks, and more to give you the tools you need to quickly populate a place your PCs can interact with.

One Spot #0 presents a pawn shop called Hand's Goods, complete with proprietor (the colorful Taylor Hand), store map, images, and more. One Spot #0: Hand's Goods is another great tool to include in your bag of GM tricks!

One Spot #0: Hand's Goods offers:

An introduction, location description, store map, and image of the doorway at the bottom of the stairs.
A bit of background on Taylor Hand, his mannerisms, and a head shot.
A suggestion of what items might currently be available for sale.
Tips on how Mr. Hand could negotiate with the PCs for items or information.
A table (10 items) of potential encounters to kick things off.




A list of hooks (4 tables of hints) for how one or more of the PCs may have interacted with the store before.

156348.name: The Painted Man
156348.description:
From publisher blurb:

No matter what system you use for your games, being a game master is a perilous pastime. As soon as the players arrive with their PCs at the ready, your well-formulated plans can go off-the-rails at a moment's notice. If you have somewhere to put the PCs for a bit while you ponder your options, it can smooth things out considerably.

If you're in need of such a location on short notice, One Spot is for you! Each product in the line focuses on a different location you can easily drop into any fantasy town or city. Instantly you have a place with NPCs, descriptive text, plot hooks, and more to give you the tools you need to quickly populate a place your PCs can interact with.

One Spot #1 presents a tavern called The Painted Man, complete with a barkeep (the artistically decorated Painted Man), tavern map, images, and more. One Spot #1: The Painted Man is another great tool to include in your bag of GM tricks!

One Spot #1: The Painted Man offers:

An introduction, location description, tavern map, and image of the tavern sign.
A bit of background on the Painted Man himself, his mannerisms, and a picture.
Descriptions for the other NPCs involved in operating the tavern, from the bubbly barmaid to the secretive owner.
A suggestion of what items might currently be on the menu and on tap.
A list (10 items) of potential facts and rumors to kick things off.
A list of hooks (4 tables of hints) for how one or more of the PCs may have interacted with the tavern before.

156349.name: Angar's Magic Shoppe
156349.description:
From publisher blurb:

No matter what system you use for your games, being a game master is a perilous pastime. As soon as the players arrive with their PCs at the ready, your well-formulated plans can go off-the-rails at a moment's notice. If you have somewhere to put the PCs for a bit while you ponder your options, it can smooth things out considerably.

If you're in need of such a location on short notice, One Spot is for you! Each product in the line focuses on a different location you can easily drop into any fantasy town or city. Instantly you have a place with NPCs, descriptive text, plot hooks, and more to give you the tools you need to quickly populate a place your PCs can interact with.

One Spot #2 presents a bookstore called Angar's Magic Shoppe, complete with a bookseller (the height-challenged but brilliant Angar Bossz), store map, images, and more. One Spot #2: Angar's Magic Shoppe is another great tool to include in your bag of GM tricks!

One Spot #2: Angar's Magic Shoppe offers:

An introduction, location description, bookstore map, and image of the sign on the window.
A bit of background on Angar Bossz himself, his mannerisms, and a picture.
Descriptions for the other NPCs involved in operating the store, including his assistant Radu and the store cat Iago.
A suggestion of how Angar operates, what he can offer, and how he deals with customers.
A list (16 items) of strange books and items Angar may have in stock.
A list of hooks (4 tables of hints) for how one or more of the PCs may have interacted with the bookstore before.

156350.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Based on the underground German phenomenon Nichteinechteswürfelspiel and updated with vintage rules, Hipster Dice is poised to be the perfect game to play while you're waiting in line at the second-hand clothing store. Get it before it's cool. It even has a pretentiously hipster name, since it only includes one die.

The rules are characteristically evasive but the gist is: there is a six-sided die. Each side of the die represents a category: music, drink, literature, fashion, movies, and food. One player rolls the die and has one minute to declare a factoid concerning the rolled subject. If everyone accepts the factoid as true, then play passes to the left. If someone challenges the factoid, then that player has two minutes to disprove the statement using whatever electronic device is handy. The winner in the challenge scores one point. The winner of the game is declared when that person scores five points. Players will have to provide their own score keeping units and electronic device for research.
156350.name: Hipster Dice
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 81-- Gen Con 2014 Top 11 to Try and Top 11 to Buy with special gues W. Eric Martin from BGG News

156351.name: Splittermond: Die Welt
156351.description:
user summary

This book gives a brief overview of the lands and people of the continent Lorakis. History, culture, society, science, politics and of course geography are all covered in this volume.

156353.description:
Objective: Move one of your 3 'Double'-figures back home - or eliminate all opponent's 'Doubles'
- moving by turns/ forward or backwards/starting positions white & black -

Abstract strategy game where players move disc-shaped pieces across an 12 by 12 cross-hatched ("checker") board.

Pieces only move diagonally, and only one or two space(s) at a time.
If a player can move one of his/her pieces so that it jumps over adjacent pieces of their opponent (only foreward, laterally or backwards - NOT diagonally) into an empty space, that player captures the opponent's discs. Jumping moves must be taken when possible.
If one of your discs reaches opponent's home base it mutates to a 'Double' (max. 3 x, after that opponent's home base is blocked). The movement range of a 'Double' is limited down to one space.

Note:
Back of the board: 'Nine Men Morris'
156353.name: Lo-Hu

156354.name: Mine
156354.description:
Cards have three pairs of dice printed on them. You roll the dice and place a chip on the matching spot on a card. When a card has all three of your chips you call "Mine" and take that card. Rolling doubles lets you remove an opponent's chip or add a chip to a card, if it's not frozen. On your turn you may freeze a card by placing your pawn on it. No other player may play on that card.

The first person to collect the designated number of cards (3-5 depending on the number of players) wins the game. With a little strategy, offense, defense, and some luck you can make the game yours.

156355.name: Medieval Warfare Rules
156355.description:
Originally published by the Society of Ancients in 1969, this set of rules was a late development of the simple Bath/Featherstone system that held sway before the days of Wargames Research Group. It is widely considered to have been the ultimate in 'fun' rules of the time. The final publication was in booklet form in 1984.

These miniatures rules are semi-skirmish level rules allowing for combats in open field, around fortifications (sieges), or on shipboard (rivercraft or boats).

Players create their own scenarios and victory conditions. Gameplay follows the typical 1960s style of simultaneous action via written orders and combat resolution via die rolls and modifiers familiar to anyone who has played early Donald Featherstone or Tony Bath ancient and medieval rules.

156356.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Today is the Festival of Aether, and your chance to prove superior magical skills and wit against your peers. Summon raw Aether from the Aether Realm and trade shrewdly with the other magi to collect a variety of Runes and Magical Elements. Use your collection to cast the best combination of Spells before the Realm closes and claim the title of Master Mage!

Aether Magic provides an engaging and exciting experience for any Mage up to the challenge!
156356.name: Aether Magic
boardgamepodcastepisode: Board Games, Business, and The Road to Kickstarter Ep. 50
Episode 37. Living Large with Happy Mitten Games
Episode 82-- LIVE from Gen Con 2014 Part 1
RDTN Episode 58 – Start Me Up: Happy Mitten Games, Ghostbusters, and Stronghold
The Seventh Peg Episode 17- Happy Mitten Games

156357.name: Trilos
156357.description:
Trilos is a game system featuring Triangular Dominoes (twenty-four Trilos and one Joker,) two playing boards, and two tile holders that include clips for tracking scores. Each Trilo has a number of pips along each side, one through nine, and has a white face on one side, black on the other. The spots on each side are the same, so that on one side the numbers run clockwise, the other anti-clockwise, which is indicated by an extra mark.

The rules describe these games for play with Trilos:

Dom Trilo – a game of drawing Trilos and matching them on a table, in an attempt to rid one's hand of any remaining tiles

Stones and Windows – two players match randomly drawn Trilos around the blank edges of the small board (a triangular grid of 10 triangles the same size as the Trilos.) The goal is to be the first to use all one's Trilos or, if reaching an unplayable position, to score the fewest points on remaining Trilos.

Rummy Trilo – three players draw seven Trilos and privately try to match a pattern drawn in the rulebook, taking turns swapping out pieces until someone completes the pattern.

Crazy Pavement – a more complicated version of Stones and Windows, with players trying to match pieces around the numbered sides of the small board, tracking several different ways to score points. When the game becomes unplayable, the score determines the winner.

Khuti – two players lay Trilos on the larger board (which features a grid of twenty-two triangles,) attempting to fill the board while outscoring each other.

Khefren – two players engage in a slightly less difficult version of the above game, Khuti.

Two Patience Games – there are two solitaire games included in the rules, Pyramid Patience and Trilex Patience.

Troulette – a game of chance utilizing a scoring board drawn in the rules and the Trilos pieces.

156358.name: The Black Rose
156358.description:
There has been a crime committed at the Monastery—and not everyone wants justice to prevail! On one side, is the manipulative and conniving Rector. On the side of justice, the Investigators.

Investigators will interview Suspects and play action cards as they attempt to avoid traps, bluffs, and interference from the Rector. At the end of each day, the Investigators meet to decide who they can trust: which Investigator is sabotaging the case and which Suspects should they accuse?

Take too long or trust the wrong person, and the guilty parties will get away. The deceptive Rector will win! Only if you use your powers of deduction to the fullest will you determine which Investigator is not what he seems, and solve the case of the Black Rose.

The Black Rose is set in Shadows of Esteren, a gothic world of suspense, secrecy and horror. This is an asymmetrical, investigative card game that is a counterpart to Vengeful Words, written by Nelyhann. No prior knowledge of Shadows of Esteren or Vengeful Words is required to play.

156359.name: Aventurischer Bote (Issue 160 - Jul/Aug 2013)
156359.description:
Issue 160 of the periodical Aventurischer Bote, the in- and outgame magazine for "Das Schwarze Auge".

The outer part contains outgame information and is separately numbered from the inner part, which contains ingame articles.

156368.name: Druids
156368.description:
Druids is played on a six-sided board divided into 88 triangular cells. There are three long sides of the board, equivalent to six of the cell's sides in length, and three short sides, two cells in length. The overall shape is of a triangle with it's points cut off, and the game's pieces (Stones) share this shape. Half of the board's cells are recessed, and divided into three color groups: black for a triangular Field in the center of the board, and red, yellow, and green for each of the Camps in the corners of the board. In each of the recessed Camp cells are a number of dots in one of these quantities: one, three, six, ten, and fifteen, with the smaller quantities being closer to the center of the board.

Each player starts play with nine Stones of the same color as his Camp, placed in all the cells of his Camp. The game is played only in the recessed cells of the board. Players take turns moving their Stones one at a time in an attempt to move all the stones of their color into one or both of their opponents' Camps. Stones may move to any one vacant adjacent cell (there are up to six adjacent recessed areas) per turn, so long as they do not re-enter their own Camp. Stones may jump over one opponent's piece to an empty adjacent cell on the opposite side; stones are not removed from the board. Jumps over friendly Stones are not allowed.

The rules allow for final scores to be tallied based on the number of dots covered by each player in their opponent's Camps, and for alternate winning conditions.

156369.description:
An Edwardian board game with graphics based on Felixstowe's course and its famous Morrello Tower. Printed rules for the game pasted down to inside box top. Invented by Sir Frederick Frankland, Bart.

Typical spin and move game. The first player, who cross the road, wins the game.
156369.name: Golfing

156370.description:
Rod Soccer is a relatively inexpensive reimplementation of the dome-style hockey games found in many arcade halls. The game combines many aspects and game play of Rod Hockey and Foosball.

Using steel rods, plastic or metal soccer players slide along defined track segments. There are five players and one goalie per side, just like in its Rod Hockey predecessor. Players simultaneously turn and move their five metal rods to pass and shoot the ball. Games can be played using a timer or to a set number of points.

Various field and ball designs have been used over the years, attempting to capture the realistic feel of soccer, while reducing bounce and the ball being ejected from the game.

Skilled players can learn how to alter their shots between "ground" balls and volley shots.

The game is light enough to be played on any elevated surface (such as a dining table or coffee table). It remains as light as the Rod Hockey predecessor.
156370.name: Rod Soccer

156371.name: x6 Core Rules (OGL)
156371.description:
from the Foreword:
x6 is a universal system for pen-and-paper roleplaying games. This core edition presents the basic game mechanics comprising the x6 system, along with a basic selection of character abilities and equipment that would suit a contemporary game setting. With some work, the information presented here can be adapted to suit a science fiction, fantasy, horror or almost any other roleplaying genre.

user comment:
This re-issue of the x6 Core rules is released under the OGL.

156372.description:
Heart of Crown: Fairy Garden is a stand-alone expansion for Heart of Crown. It contains all the cards from the base game to play on its own, and may be integrated with the cards of the base game and the other Heart of Crown expansions.

The set contains 230 cards:

A full set of the basic cards necessary to play the game:
12 Apprentice Maids
12 Court Maids
12 Senators
12 Dukes
48 Villages
30 Towns
20 Cities
16 Curse Cards

6 Princess Cards, reprinted from the base game and incorporating the latest revisions to their game text.
2 Rare Cards
Imperial Crown (reprinted from the base game)
Fairy Queen Elrune (replaces "Imperial Karikuma" from the base game)

30 new types of Common Card (5 of each card)
16 Action Cards
9 Attack Cards
3 Land Cards
2 Succession Cards

30 Placeholder Cards (1 for each new type of Common Card)
156372.name: Heart of Crown: Fairy Garden

156373.description:
Chimera is a three-player card game of two against one similar to climbing- and shedding-based card games like Tichu, The Great Dalmuti, Big Two and Beat the Landlord.

Each hand, one player is designated Chimera and the other two players team up as Chimera Hunters to defeat the Chimera. Players compete for points in several hands of play by playing sequential pairs, trips, straights and other card combinations, and whoever has scored the most points once the designated point score has been reached wins. Chimera is normally played to 400 points, although longer or shorter games can be played.
156373.name: Chimera
boardgamefamily: Z-Man / Filosofia deluxe card game series
boardgamepodcastepisode: An Entourage of Swift Canoes
Episode 36: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy and Wisdom Check 1
Episode 39: Chimera, Diamonds and Best/Worst of 2014
Episode 63 - Cry Havoc
Episode 78-- Star Studded Origins 2014 Wrap Up
Essen 2015 - Abacusspiele
GenCon 2014 - Z-Man Games

156374.name: A Time of Eclipse
156374.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Time of Eclipse is an ePub/Mobi file containing roughly the first 111 pages of the '''Eclipse Phase''' core rulebook: essentially, all of the setting material from the core!

We are working on converting the rest of Eclipse Phase to ePub format.

156375.name: Harlekin Game
156375.description:
This game relies on placing money on a small board in accordance with dice thrown. The player places some money on the number that represents what the player throws. In the 1800 version, money placed equates to one cent.

If there is already a cent placed, the players takes that money and throws the dice again. He/she takes money as long as there is already money placed, and places money as soon as a number is thrown that is empty on the board.

If a player has no more money to place, the player may throw the dice once more. If the player does not receive money on that turn, the player is out.

The game continues until there is only one player left, who collects all the remaining money.

This game is related to Harlekin och hans sju korvar and Der Deutsche Hanswurst, though the game intent here is a game for money and placement of coins (the others are roll and move games)

156376.name: Kreuz und Quer
156376.description:
Objective: Be the first moving all of your ten meeples into target positions (two coloured crosses)
- moving by turns -
Each player chooses a colour placing his/her 10 meeples into starting positions (colour matching corner).

During a turn each player moves one own meeple (with a knight's move in Chess). Spaces with other meeples can't be entered, also opponent's target positions block. There are four central positions which must be cleaned during next turn; other wise your meeple is sent back to starting position.

Note:
Likely publishd during 1930's

156377.name: 4 Soccer Simulators
videogameversion: English/European Amstrad CPC (Codemasters Budget) Cassette edition
English/European ZX Spectrum (Codemasters Budget) Cassette edition
156377.description:
User Summary

Four Soccer Simulators is a compilation of four previously unreleased soccer games. Three were different versions of soccer, a full outdoor 11-a-side game, an indoor 5-a-side game and a street soccer game, complete with obstacles such as cars, trees etc. The final game was a Soccer Skills mini-game compilation in the Hyper-Sports mould.

Amiga and Atari ST versions (under the name "Pro Soccer Simulator") were advertised, but not released.

From the Inlay

11-A-SIDE SOCCER - This is it - THE soccer game. It's got everything - fouls, corners, goalckicks[sic], penalties, throwins, off-side and much, much more. Play the computer or friends - you'll love this game, it's ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT!

INDOOR SOCCER - Real 5-a-side soccer with full indoor rules. There's fast action and loads of goals because play isn't interrupted by throwins corners or goalkicks - the ball just bounces off the walls - A TRUE SIMULATOR!

STREET SOCCER - Excellent fun - soccer with no rules! Hack the other players and watch them roll around in agony! Be careful - don't lose the ball over a wall. You'll have great fun as you shoot the cars, off the houses and around the trees. JUST LIKE THE REAL THING!

SOCCER SKILLS - You've gotta train hard to be the best... 100m sprints, take penalties, goalie practice, dribble around cones, press-ups, sit-ups - faster! - bench jumps, weight lifting, full circuit training AND MORE!

Credits (ZX Spectrum inlay)

Four Soccer Simulators was brought to you by...

GAME DESIGN Peter Williamson
David and Richard Darling
Mark Baldock
GAME CODING Gavin Raeburn and
Smart Egg Software
GRAPHICS Gavin Raeburn
Tim Millar
MUSIC/SOUND FX Gavin Raeburn
PRODUCTION Stew Regan
Shân Savage
COVER ILLUSTRATION Rod Walker

156378.name: Understanding the Pool
156378.description:
from the essay:
"The Pool did not begin the independent play-and-design revolution any more than the Forge itself did. But it was the linchpin upon which dialogue at the Forge underwent a profound change, breaking techniques out of game-specific packages, which itself spurred design, play, and commerce into a quantum leap of content and reflection."

"Without The Pool, no Universalis, no Donjon, no Wyrd, no Dust Devils, no later-stage InSpectres, no Violence Future, no Dead Meat, no Otherkind, no The World The Flesh & The Devil, and no Legends of Alyria. And without those, no Trollbabe and no My Life with Master, and without those, no Shadow of Yesterday, no Dogs in the Vineyard, no Nine Worlds, and no Primetime Adventures."

user comment:
An essay about a touchstone of indie game design, written by a well-known indie game designer.

156379.name: Howler (3.5/OGL)
156379.description:
from the title page:
Doomslakers Adventures #1

from the back cover:
The wind whips through the standing stones making the hill moan like something alive. Or perhaps something dead. You stand atop its barren crown. There is a whisper in the darkness. There is evil afoot…Whether you come to the hill for glory, riches, or by mere chance you might not walk away the same as when you came…if at all

This OGL module for low-level characters can be used with most fantasy role playing games

from the introduction:
This adventure is for a party of 4 to 6 characters of levels 1st to 3rd. It is intended to be a short, single session dungeon crawl you can either drop into a longer adventure or run as a side trek. The area is not described in much detail so you can easily fit it into most medieval fantasy campaigns. Any specifics of the setting, such as the Shekeltooth goblin clan or the elves of Pricklewood forest, are part of a fantasy world that could develop from this and future adventures in the Doomslakers line. Feel free to include or exclude any of these these elements to suit your needs.

156380.name: Howler (OSRIC)
rpg: Old School Reference and Index Compilation (OSRIC)
156380.description:
from the title page:
Doomslakers Adventures #1

from the back cover:
HOWLER
An original advanced module of adventure!

The wind whips through the standing stones making the hill moan like something alive. Or perhaps something dead. You stand atop its barren crown. There is a whisper in the darkness. There is evil afoot…Whether you come to the hill for glory, riches, or by mere chance you might not walk away the same as when you came…if at all

This module for low-level characters can be used with most fantasy role playing games and is fully compatible with OSRIC

from the introduction:
This adventure is for a party of 4 to 6 characters of levels 1st to 3rd. It is compatible with OSRIC – the Oldschool System Reference and Index Compilation created by Matthew Finch and Stuart Marshall. If you like playing the original advanced game you'll love OSRIC...

Howler is intended to be a single session dungeon crawl you can either drop into a longer adventure or run as a side trek. The area is not described in much detail so you can easily fit it into most medieval fantasy campaigns. Any specifics of the setting, such as the Shekeltooth goblin clan or the elves of Pricklewood forest, are part of a fantasy world that could develop from this and future adventures in the Doomslakers line. Feel free to include or exclude any of these elements to suit your needs.

156381.name: Dwarves of Iron Peak
156381.description: DWARVES OF IRON PEAK is a competitive 2 player board game that pits a band of Dwarves, bent on recovering the lost treasure of King Dorum, against an enormous and greedy Mountain Troll. The game plays anywhere from 20-30 minutes, where-in the Dwarves strive to recapture the Relic of the Iron Peak and the covetous Troll defends HIS treasure at any cost.

156382.name: Coastal Fort
156382.description:
From the introduction

The fort is not terribly large but it controls access to the harbor quite well anyway. Situated in a location that gets flooded by the tides regularly and surrounded by dangerously sharp rock needles the guns behind the fort's battlements are only the final determent to any would be attacker. While the regular flooding protects the fort from siege by land and the dangerous rock needles protect it from most attacks from the seaside this makes the fort hard to supply as well. While the guns are formidable their number and especially the amount of ammunition available for them is quite limited. Still, so far no attacker has been determined enough to try and outlastthe garrison and their guns.

156383.name: Gasometer
156383.description:
From the introduction

Partially obscured by earthen embankments and a high steel fence topped with barbed wire rolls are these two voluminous gas tanks only part of a much larger industrial complex. These gasometers are only part of a storage network for the gas needed here. The pipes disappearing into the ground as well as the access hatches to the underground shut-off valves are a strong hint to this fact. Very few people know this fact though and even fewer would be allowed to get this close. After all the two spheres store enough gas for quite a spectacular firework. Even the maintenance workers allowed to approach them are rather uneasy when at the site.

156384.name: Pilot Down: Behind Enemy Lines
156384.description:
From the back of the English/European PS2 case:

Based on a true story...
In World War 2 over 180,000 allied airmen were shot down over occupied territory. Only 300 made it to Switzerland and freedom. Will you be one of them?


Overcome relentless SS troops, the biting cold and treacherous terrain
Pit your wits against sophisticated Artificial Intelligence
Explore vast environments packed with real weapons, vehicles and foes
Unique adventure experience, fusing stealth, tactics and action

156386.name: Diamond Mine
156386.description:
From the manual

The object of Diamond Mine is to drive your Subterranean Mining Vehicle through each mine shaft, pick up the diamonds,
process them in the special Diamond Processing Area, and
take them out of the mine shaft without being killed. You begin
the game with five vehicles.

You don't have to worry about cave-ins, black-lung disease
and ordinary dangers like that. These are special mine shafts
in which many different types of monstrosities lurk. They have
no intention of letting you escape with their precious diamonds. . .and will stop you if you let them.

156387.name: Über Epic
boardgamepodcastepisode: The First Roll - What's New on Kickstarter? - Episode 68: Tuesday, September 20th
156387.description:
Über Epic is a social strategy game for 2-12 players that play on 2-4 teams. Players control characters to achieve Epic Goals, attack opponents' bases to capture their flag, and defend their own flag. Use walls to build your defenses to slow opponents from capturing your flag. Artifact cards — featuring single-use items or immediate effects that either hurt or help you — are located around the neutral zone, which is a circular board.

Teams gain Über Points (UPs) by scoring hits on opponents via ranged or melee attacks, achieving Epic Goals, or capturing an opponent's flag, and the team with the most UPs wins.

156388.name: The Tome of Decay
156388.description:
From the back of North American release edition

Black Crusade
The Tome of Decay
Accept the Joyous Blessings of the Plaguefather!

Nurgle is the Chaos God of Death, Decay, and Rebirth. To those who accept his foul embrace, the Lord of Pestilence offers power over plagues, vermin, and even the inevitable grasp of entropy.

This book introduces putrid new Heretic Archetypes, as well as vile weapons and rules for Daemonic Possession, for forging Daemon Engines, and even for undergoing the grand apotheosis to Daemonhood.

This tome also includes rules for launching a Black Crusade, giving Heretics the chance to put the skills they have honed and the forces they have gathered in the Screaming Vortex to the ultimate test!

This volume contains descriptions of many of the blighted worlds of the Screaming Vortex, along with their depraved inhabitants! Trudging across the swampy realm of Mire, the Heretics can make their way into the very eye of the storm in the adventure The Heart of the Vortex!

Let nothing stop your inexorable stride to spread Nurgle's infectious gifts to all!

A copy of Black Crusade Core Rulebook is needed to use this supplement.

From the publisher's webpage:

Focusing on Nurgle, the Chaos God of pestilence and plague, The Tome of Decay, a supplement for Black Crusade, serves up all manner of ailments, resources, allies, and ideas for Nurgle’s grotesque followers. The Tome of Decay also includes advice for GMs on running their own plague-filled campaigns!

In addition to powerful new allies and ailments for the twisted followers of Nurgle, this volume contains many new resources for heretics of all sorts, whether they worship one of the Ruinous Powers or their own ambition. The Tome of Decay includes the Warpsmith and Veteran of the Long War Archetypes, whose endless war against the Imperium has sharpened them into peerless killers, and rules that allow Heretics to forge their own Daemon Engines or even bind Daemons within their own bodies to become powerful Possessed champions of Chaos. Finally, this Tome contains the rules for ascension to Daemonhood and running one’s own Black Crusade, allowing the most powerful Heretics to take the fight against the servants of the False Emperor to terrible new heights.

156389.name: KIN: Speed Freaks
156389.description:
In this game you take the role as a pro racer in a tropical island paradise far far away from our Universe to compete in a steam speeder race. You will race over land and water, in high speed through the jungle aboard your wooden hover craft. You race for honor and glory both for yourself and your tribe.

- Twelve different characters to choose from, everyone with their own unique skill and personality.
- Play with or without random event cards and joker tokens.
- 3 game mats printed on both sides gives you the possibilty to build 12 different race courses.
- You can choose lenght of the course and the number of laps to adopt the game depending on how much time you have to spare.
- Random event cards makes the race more challenging (you can also play without cards).

By spending actions you move (roll a dice and move), try to make life miserable for your opponents by taunting or bumping them (slow them down) or do stunty manouvers (roll and pass). You will also use your actions to change lane and most likely to repair.

It's not just about rolling the dice and you will have to make strategic decisions during the race.

There are many ways to race the race and each character have their own special skill that you can add to your playing style.

156390.name: Quer durch Asien
156390.description:
Objective:
Be the first to reach Tokio (starting from Istanbul or St. Petersburg)
- moving by turns/simple 'Roll & Move' game -
Pay money to buy in - choose one of four different routes (dotted or drawn through) and matching pawn.

Roll the dice and move forward - ending on a marked space follow instructions. First, second and third player earn bonus.

Notes:
Likely published during 1910's
As usual - cute pewter pawns

156391.name: Türme im Eis
156391.description:
from the back of the book

Up in the north Dragoreas, in the deep forests of the kingdom Wintholt, are the ruins of ancient fortresses witnesses of a bygone era.
The theft of a piece of jewelry leads the adventurers from the streets of the capital Albronnen deep into the history of Wintholt, and out into the impenetrable wilderness in search of the secrets of a time when the moon was still unshattered in the sky.

156392.name: Splittermond Schnellstart-Regeln, Gratisrollenspieltag-Ausgabe
156392.description:
user summary

Quickstart rules, including an adventure module.
Printed for the Gratisrollenspieltag, the german equivalent of the Free RPG-Day.

156393.description:
Defender of Vigil is the January 2014 promo card for Ascension.

Gain 2 Rune and 2 Power.
Gain 1 Rune for each Apprentice you play or have played this turn.
Gain 1 Power for each Militia you play or have played this turn.
156393.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Defender of Vigil Promo

156394.description:
Foul Replicant is the February 2014 promo for Ascension.

Foul Replicant - Trophy Monster - Needs: 5 strength
Reward: Gain 4 Honor
Ongoing Trophy: Once per turn, choose a Construct you control. This gains the text of the chosen Construct for this turn.
156394.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Foul Replicant Promo

156395.name: Prime Time: The Ratings Game
156395.description:
PRIME TIME: The Ratings Game is a card game for 1-4 Players that puts you in charge of a major television network.

In PRIME TIME: The Ratings Game you are the head of a television network. It is up to you to create shows that will attract the highest ratings and beat out your rivals. At the start of the game your schedule is a blank slate. You will have to program shows for Monday to Friday night. You do this by programming (playing) cards onto the table. These cards represent the shows, actors, commercial breaks and more. At the end of the game, whoever has the highest rated shows on each night will “win” that night. Each night is worth points. The player with the most points wins the game.

Cast the actors, come up with special twists and don’t forget to program some commercials to pay for it all. What shows you create and when you program them are all up to you. Will you fight for the coveted Thursday night-time slot with a prestigious big budget show or try to tie up Monday and Tuesday nights with cheap programming? It’s up to you to take your network to the top of the charts and be the leader of Prime Time.

156396.name: Aventurischer Bote (Issue 162 - Nov/Dec 2013)
156396.description:
Issue 162 of the periodical Aventurischer Bote, the in- and outgame magazine for "Das Schwarze Auge".

The outer part contains outgame information and is separately numbered from the inner part, which contains ingame articles.

156397.name: Modern Adventures
156397.description:
From publisher blurb:

Modern Adventures is an supplement to the Pathfinder Roleplaying game published by Paizo, designed to expand Pathfinder for modern settings. Not just a rehash of d20 Modern,* Modern Adventures is a new take on fantasy gaming in a 21st century setting. Inside, you'll find:

Updates to the existing Pathfinder Roleplaying Game classes and races, bringing them into the 21st century.
6 brand new classes with 20 new archetypes.
Charmer: Masters of the social arts, charmers are masters of flattery and persuasion, using their innate appeal to deceive, manipulate, and bend others to their will.
Archetypes: Animal Whisperer, Gambler, Romancer, Undercover Spy

Entertainer: Consummate performers, entertainers are happiest in front of an audience. They create and control the raw emotions of everyone around them. As they advance in levels they also gain status and influince.
Archetypes: Stand-up Comic, Pro Athlete, Stuntman

Gadgeteer: Techies. Gearheads. Geeks. Rocket Scientists. Whatever you call them, gadgeteers are technological virtuosos, able to create short-lived gizmos - technology so advanced it makes "cutting-edge" look like a blunt rock.
Archetypes: Hacker, Racer, Saboteur

Investigator: Investigators are tireless seekers of truth and insatiable puzzle-solvers, never content unless they're working a case. Using flashes of intuition as well as the scientific re-creation of crime scenes, no clue is beyond their reach.
Archetypes: Bounty Hunters, Gentleman Detective, Muckraker, Superfan

Scholar: Part bookworm, part mad scientist, the scholar's primary advantage is their raw intellect which they can shape into various talents and tricks. They can also create concoctions that can have either beneficial or detrimental effects.
Archetypes: Engineer, Psychologist

Stranger: Every culture produces individuals who ultimately live apart from it, strangers within their own lands. Whether driven away from society or choosing to live apart from their fellow man, strangers face scorn and derision wherever they go. Still, living outside the system lets them accomplish things that most 9-5ers can only dream about.
Archetypes: Drunken Bum, Parolee, Street Preacher, Traditional Tribal Warrior


New Skills
New Feats
New Spells
New Afflictions
200 Full Color Illustrations
Modern weapons, equipment, and vehicles.
2 campaign universes and sample adventures:
Fifth Realm: The nine worlds of Norse mythology are real... and on a collision course with Midgard, the fifth realm. Participate in the return of magic to the modern world. Explore 8 new dimensional planes and, most importantly, defend earth from magically adept alien invaders.
Silicon Gothic: A hard sci-fi universe completely devoid of magic, the near-future world of Silicon Gothic follows the dystopian footsteps of Bladerunner, Brazil, Escape From New York, Max Headroom, Metropolis, and Robocop. Corrupt and greedy corporations oppress their workers and bully the powerless government. You must learn to work the system or be crushed by it.





(*) OK, a good deal of the equipment list is carried over from d20 Modern. You've got me. Did you really expect us to re-research everyday items that everybody already knows?

156398.name: Nemesis
156398.description:
From publisher blurb:

NEMESIS!

Created by the evil geniuses at P.U.R.G.E. and modified by H.A.D.E.S., the android Nemesis will be the end of heroes around the world. Able to scan and counter almost any power he encounters, Nemesis is on the loose and ready to spread his brand of evil in your next game!

156399.name: The Bank
156399.description:
From publisher blurb:

This Product is a 48 x 30 inch, Black and White Blueprint of a Bank.

The Product comes with the Hex, Square and No Overlay versions and the Virtual Tabletop Maps.

“Hey I ain’t asking you to break in and rob the place. All I want you to do is switch this note with one like it in the safe deposit boxes. Now how you do that is entirely up to you.”

The Bank is a hand-drawn, black and white, blueprint style map. The product includes the floor plan of the ground floor of a large bank. Each individual room in the house is labeled and includes hand-drawn objects signifying all of the furnishings of the room.

The Bank is intended for use in modern games. It could also easily be used in near future science fiction games.

Adventure hook for use with this product.

The Note: A middle-aged man contacts the Player Characters wanting to exchange a note in a safe deposit box in the local bank with the one in his possession. The man seems to know that they are freelancers or petty criminals with skills at deception, stealth, and theft. The note is in a sealed envelope with a wax seal.

If the Player Characters decide to tamper with the note they find a forged will, which leaves all the possessions of his parents to the middle-aged man. Their combined assets are worth about 250K, paltry compared to the 2.5K offered to the group for the task. They could decide to refuse the job or go back and renegotiate with their employer. If they seem to let on that they know the scheme, the middle age man ups the ante to 25K, figuring that they might just be competent enough to pull this off. Of course, if they decline he now has no choice but to off them and look for some new employees. A man who has decided to kill his own parents after all has no moral qualms about killing people he just met.

If the Player Characters accept the job, it is up to them to figure out how to get into the safe deposit room and make the exchange. They could break in to the bank of night. They could also steal the safe deposit key from the man’s parents’ house, disguise themselves to look like the parents, and just walk into the safe deposit room to make the exchange. They could also attempt to distract the security officer(s) on duty and disable the recording devices in the monitoring room, and then switch documents. If they think to read the document they switched out, the will gives most of the money to the man’s younger brother instead with a small amount to their employer.

With the deed done, the middle-aged man puts the hit on his parents. If he trusts the Player Characters after this job, he might even offer them the contract. The big thing is that it has to look like an accident of course...

156400.name: Prestigeous Organizations: The Order of the Nullblades
156400.description:
From publisher blurb:

"Absolute power corrupts absolutely."

This story, like so many others, begins with an old man in a tavern; he was not the wise old man of so many clichéd tales of fantasy, but rather a wizard who was completely and utterly smashed on the local nectar. Needless to say, the tavern goers were nervous. A crazy guy grabbing a chair and smashing another guy over the head was something they could understand and run from, but a drunken wizard who is likely able to turn anyone who makes any sudden movements into a newt for a few days? Why, that is something else entirely. Finally getting fed up with this pointless standoff, over a few silver on a tab, no less, an adventuring fighter stepped up to put an end to this.

After recovering from being a newt for nearly two weeks, the fighter decided that enough was enough. Something, anything, had to be done about these blasted spellcasters! Though his knowledge of magic was miniscule, he recalled that magic, particularly divination, had issues around lead. Thus laden with lead-based talcum powders from the local alchemist, the fighter went on to make almost impossible victories against obnoxious users of magic, that is until he died of lead poisoning a little over a year later.

Rallying around this man, now seen a martyr, a number of fighters and clerics of arcane-hating gods continued his crusade. Calling themselves The Order of the Nullblades, these individuals are committed to the elimination of the "misuse of magic" and can be seen battling mad wizards, planar incursions, and strange arcane anomalies the world over, for a price, of course.

Product Features:

Organization overview for The Order of the Nullblades, including ranks and responsibilities, business model, internal politics, chain of command and several ways for PCs to get involved with the Order that just scream "Easy plot hook!"
Rules for randomly generating chapterhouses in settlements, including special amenities that nullblades can use
The nullblade prestige class
NPC writeups for Drimble Underhill, halfling knight-champion of the Order (CR 8 fighter/nullblade) and Cerabiel, elven chaptermaster of the Order (CR 12 bard [arcane duelist]/fighter/nullblade)

156401.name: Distant Vistas (Savage Worlds Edition)
156401.description:
From publisher blurb:

Picking up where the [Eldritch Skies Rulebook] left off, Distant Vistas expands the universe with new options and new additions.

Covering such topics as mining, to exploring strange new systems, between these covers are mysteries that reach to the very core of humankind’s voyages to the stars.

156402.name: Eldritch Skies (Savage Worlds Edition)
156402.description:
From publisher blurb:

Battlefield Press presents its ENnie Award 2013 winning setting now for the Savage Worlds game engine.

It is 2030. The Gilman-Hawking drive has given us access to the stars. But we are not alone.

They're out there: aliens, gods and monsters. They're also down here. The Miskatonic Antarctic Expedition found the elder ones' city in 1931. The mi-go crashed in Roswell in 1947.

In 1958, as quietly as possible, not knowing what we were doing, we bent occult powers to our hands and took the step to Mars. The third time, the men who made that step could not step back. We fled back into our cave for a while.

But rocketry, and the Soviets, brought us back out soon enough. Competition took us to the moon. Uneasy teamwork saved the astronauts who would have died there among cyclopean, immemorial ruins.

In 1994, human scientists cracked alien technology and overcame the lightspeed barrier. They brought us the stars. They also brought us the madness that lies between them, the mind-twisting undarkness of hyperspace.

The future is here. Machine-made telepathy, augmentations, and unprecedented levels of automation have changed the face of Earth. But the science of sorcery, and our primitive understandings of what lies outside, have changed more than our minuscule planet. They've begun to let humanity out.

We walk amongst giants. Tread carefully.

156403.name: Metal Gods of Ur-Hadad (Issue 1 - Winter 2014)
rpg: Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game
156403.description:
From the publisher's website:

In this issue of the Metal Gods of Ur-Hadad you will find:


20 pages of Metal-drenched DCC mayhem.
Background info on the Metal Gods and Ur-Hadad.
The paradoxical problem of Assassins in Ur-Hadad.
The staggeringly-amazing Street Kids of Ur-Hadad urban funnel adventure tool kit! Remember The Warriors? Edgar Johnson gives you all the tools you need to make your own urchin-grinding funnel adventure version of it.
A ton of art by the excellent Mr. Wayne Snyder, as well as a short, "one page dungeon"–style insert by him, ready to be slipped into your next DCC session.

156404.name: Tappingo
156404.description:
"Solve pixel art puzzles by making numbered blocks extend into lines. Sounds easy? wait until you find out these lines keep running unless they hit something! Be smart and use other blocks and lines to stop the line at the correct length.

Features

Line running action that will make your brain crack!
100 puzzles for you to solve!
Divided over small and big grids!
Game keeps track of time it took to solve a puzzle... can you beat it?
Awesome funky fresh artstyle and tunes!"




Source: The Game Website.

156405.description:
Objective - as a dog: block and catch the fox;
as fox: survive (for at least 10 min.) or escape
- moving by turns -

Three dogs try to catch a fox in a labyrinth; fox is placed into the centre, dogs (are split into players) move in from 3 exits.
Fourth exit is blocked by the hunter. Fox may use a double step once.

Note:
Likely published 1950's
156405.name: Auf zur Fuchsjagd

156406.name: The Chronicles of Dragon Wing
156406.description: This is a DotA(Defense of the Ancients)/LoL(League of Legends) like boardgame with a fantasy theme. In the game, players are divided into two teams to compete with each other. They can move on the hexagonal grids, play cards and use their heroes' unique powers to win an advantage over their opponents, with the aim of destroying the opponent team's base.

156407.description:
The famous TV show "Room 25" is back for a new season with two characters joining the cast: the adventurer and the psychopath.

In Room 25: season 2, an extension for Room 25, all characters have their own special ability. Also, thanks to an adrenaline surge, the participants can perform one additional action in a turn of their choice. Of course we've made the complex different — and more difficult — by adding new rooms...will you be up to the challenge?
156407.name: Room 25: Season 2
boardgamepodcastepisode: [FIJ Cannes 2014] Room 25 Saison 2

156409.name: Al-Qadim 3.5
156409.description:
user summary:
AQ 3.5 provides the mechanical information necessary to use the Al-Qadim setting with D&D 3.5. The guide consists of eight chapters dealing with various aspects of character creation and other mechanical information unique to the setting. It is distributed as a set of individual files, one per topic:


Races, 9 pp.
Core Classes, 21 pp.
Prestige Classes, 13 pp.
Background Feats, 6 pp.
Languages, 1 p.
Equipment, 5 pp.
Provinces of Magic, 6 pp.
Other Rules, 7 pp.

156410.name: Aftershock
156410.description:
delta-green.com blurb:
You are to contact Detective Luis Sears of San Antonio Police Department. He requires discreet assistance in apprehending one Brian James, who he suspects may have some unnatural powers at his disposal. James was arrested by officers after causing a disturbance on 03/30/2012 in the reception of Penick Tower, telling everyone to leave, claiming that the building was due to collapse, and that they would be killed. He never reached the station, as the patrol car was found a distance away, both officers incapacitated, but with no signs of a struggle. One has been admitted to SASH, the State Psychiatric Hospital.

An earthquake then did occur a few days later in San Antonio, magnitude 5.6, which is the highest on record for the city. It occurred on 04/02/2012 at 0916, and the Penick Tower did partially collapse, causing some loss of life.

Objectives


Assist Detective Sears in safely apprehending the subject, and interview him to assess his accurate prediction of the quake.



Briefly assess the earthquake and subsequent damage to determine if there is anything unusual about it. Make use of professional resources such as USGS.



return encrypted email.


Possible friendly contacts


Hank Long, local amateur meteorologist

156411.name: Κόντρα στο χρόνο
156411.description:
It 's a very amusing party game. Some general knowledge and tactics also help.

Every player takes a card with twelve numbered 'questions'. For example
1. mountain in Europe
2. Something sharp
3. vegetable
4. Outdoor occupation
5. Kind of wine
6. Literature's hero
7. City if south America
8. Something yellow
9. word with 4 letters
10. newspaper
11. metal
12. something you take on a trip

Then another card is drawn that shows one letter.
Every player has to write a word for each 'question' 1-12 starting with this letter within 2 minutes. Then comes scoring, in which is better to give unique answers.

There are also two more ways to play this game, which make it even more replayable.

156412.name: Bloemeneiland
156412.description:
Bloemeneiland - the Island of Flowers - is a game for 2 or 3 players who are flower buyers for the King. Players must buy flowers from the local merchants and growers and send them by ship back to the Palace to gain favor at court. The player with the most favor after six rounds is the winner.

Playing the game:
Beginning with the round’s Starting Player, players take clockwise turns doing 2 actions in order.

Action 1: Players must move the Island Marker on the board in a clockwise direction from one Townsperson space to another (or to the Dock). They may move any number of spaces but only the first space moved is free. Each additional space costs 1 gold. If the marker stops in front of a Townsperson that player will receive a benefit if they choose. If the player stops at the Dock they
will cause all players to deliver flowers to the Ship.

Action 2: After the player visits a Townsperson they must move their numbered Player Marker to a Location which matches the Townsperson’s colored border. Locations occupied by another player may not be visited. You may then use the Location’s Special Action. If the Island Marker is at the Dock, no Locations may be used.

If the Island Marker is at the Dock, all players may now choose to deliver flowers to the Ship and gain Favor Points. Beginning with the round’s Starting Player and then continuing clockwise, each player may deliver one type of flower to the ship, but never more than the Palace currently demands as valued by the dice in play. After each delivery, adjust the corresponding die down by the number of flowers delivered.
